author: Deleted User
content: I think things might get a little crazy as we get closer toward the end of the year. Is there room for further blocksize increases or is the idea that "smart" blocksize by EIP1559 will handle any further load?

author: Deleted User
content: I think that total altcoin marketcap might reach $4T around New Years Eve. Thats a 4x from here. Pretty wild if true

author: timbeiko
content: Price comments aside, and please refrain from those in this server, <@456226577798135808>, the blocksize could still be increased after 1559. Right after London, the max block size will be 30m and the average will still be ~15m. There is always a cost in increasing the block size (state growth), but if the community feels the benefits outweigh them, it could be increased.

author: Deleted User
content: is anyone concerned about a feedback loop where the fee burning becomes so significant that it creates an ETH shortage, which causes the price to go up, which generates media attention, which draws in more users, which raises fee burning even further, which creates a bigger shortage which generates even more media attention... so on

author: foxis86
content: There are still 2 ETH block rewards being generated in each block. I doubt burned fees will be  higher than 2 eth. So it's not completely deflationary.

author: timbeiko
content: This is there reason there is a gas *price*. The fiat price of ETH doesn't affect how much gas is used by a transaction, but it can affect the gas *price*. For example, if you send a 21000 txn, you may pay a gas price of 100 gwei if ETH is 2000$. If ETH was 20000$ instead, you could pay a gas price of 10 gwei instead and still pay the same USD-denominated fee.

author: Deleted User

author: timbeiko
content: They can: because of DeFi I suspect fees are more correlated with price volatility than absolute price
